case_id: Machhi Singh & Ors v. State of Punjab (1983)
facts: Parties Involved: Machhi Singh & Ors (Appellants), State of Punjab (Respondent)
Multiple murders were committed by the appellants.
The motive behind the murders was related to caste rivalry and political enmity.
The accused were tried and convicted under Section 302 read with Section 149 of the Indian Penal Code by the Sessions Court.
The High Court confirmed the conviction and sentence.
The appellants filed an appeal to the Supreme Court challenging the conviction and sentence.

prosecution_arguments.argument: The accused formed an unlawful assembly with the common object of committing murder, and the murders were committed in furtherance of that common object.
precedents: Barendra Kumar Ghose v. Emperor (1925) 52 IA 40: Established the principle of constructive liability in common intention.
Mahbub Shah v. Emperor AIR 1945 PC 118: Defines the distinction between common intention and similar intention.
Krishna Govind Patil v. State of Maharashtra AIR 1963 SC 1413:  Explains the scope of Section 149 and the requirement of active participation or presence with a common object.
elements: Existence of an unlawful assembly (5 or more persons).
Common object of the assembly must be unlawful.
The offence (murder) must have been committed in prosecution of the common object or that the members of the assembly knew it to be likely to be committed.
The accused were members of the unlawful assembly and shared the common object.
Causation: The act must have been committed in furtherance of the common object.
Active Participation (may be active or constructive).

counter_arguments.loophole: Proof of the common object might be insufficient, or the accused might not have shared the common object.
supporting_precedents: Nanu Singh v. State of M.P. AIR 2002 SC 873: Mere presence in an unlawful assembly is not enough to attract Section 149.
State of U.P. v. Ram Sagar Yadav AIR 1985 SC 416:  The common object must be proved beyond reasonable doubt.
Dukhi Sao v. State of Bihar AIR 1958 SC 382: It must be clearly established that the accused shared the common object

prosecution_arguments.argument: Each accused is individually liable for murder under Section 302, read with Section 34, due to a pre-arranged plan and common intention to commit the crime.
precedents: Pandurang Tukia and Bhillia v. State of Maharashtra AIR 1963 SC 118 : Highlights the need to prove pre-arranged plan for Section 34 application.
Richpal Singh v. State of Haryana AIR 1974 SC 301: The acts must be committed in furtherance of the common intention.
Ashok Kumar v. State of U.P. AIR 2008 SC 2859: Common intention implies a pre-arranged plan.
elements: Common intention to commit the crime (murder).
The acts of the accused were done in furtherance of the common intention.

counter_arguments.loophole: Insufficient evidence to prove a pre-arranged plan or common intention among all the accused.
supporting_precedents: Ram Bilas Singh v. State of Bihar AIR 1964 SC 145:  Mere similarity of intention is not enough; there must be a pre-arranged plan.
Jasbir Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1976 SC 97:  Absence of a pre-concerted plan can weaken the application of Section 34.
Rajesh Govind Jagesha v. State of Maharashtra (1999) 8 SCC 428 : No direct evidence of pre-arranged plan.

defense_arguments.argument: Doubtful identification of the accused. The prosecution's case rests on unreliable eyewitness accounts.
edge_cases: Lack of corroboration of eyewitness accounts.
Poor visibility or lighting conditions at the time of the incident.
precedents: Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras AIR 1957 SC 614: Categorizes witnesses and emphasizes the need for caution with solitary witnesses.
State of U.P. v. Anil Singh AIR 1988 SC 2058: Highlights the importance of scrutiny of eyewitness testimony, especially in cases of mass violence.
Rana Pratap v. State of Haryana AIR 1983 SC 680: Emphasizes the need for corroboration of eyewitness testimony, particularly when witnesses are closely related to the deceased.

defense_arguments.argument: There was no common intention between the accused and they were falsely implicated in the case due to political rivalry. Section 149 cannot be invoked as the assembly was not unlawful.
edge_cases: Lack of proof of unlawful assembly.
Lack of clarity about the common object of the assembly.
False implication due to political rivalry and enmity.
precedents: Chittarmal v. State of Rajasthan AIR 2003 SC 1496: Highlights the necessity of proving the common object to invoke Section 149.
Rijwanul Haque v. State of U.P. AIR 2009 SC 2211: Mere presence is not sufficient; active participation is required for Section 149.
Masalti v. State of U.P. AIR 1965 SC 202: Emphasizes the requirement of the common object being unlawful for Section 149 to apply.

judgment.outcome: The Supreme Court formulated principles for when the death penalty should be awarded, characterizing the case as falling within the 'rarest of rare cases'. Confirmed the conviction and upheld the death penalty.
reasoning: The Supreme Court held that the collective murders demonstrated exceptional depravity and cruelty. The motive of caste rivalry was also taken into consideration.
The Court emphasized the need to consider the aggravating and mitigating circumstances of the crime and the criminal.
The Court laid down guidelines for determining whether a case falls within the 'rarest of rare cases' for awarding the death penalty.
cited_cases: Jagmohan Singh v. State of U.P. (1973) 1 SCC 20
Rajendra Prasad v. State of U.P. (1979) 3 SCC 646
Bachan Singh v. State of Punjab (1980) 2 SCC 684
